name: Tao
shortDescription: The Way - the ineffable source and principle underlying all existence in Daoist philosophy
fullDescription: The Tao (ÈÅì, D√†o, also Dao) is the fundamental, ineffable principle at the heart of Daoist philosophy - the nameless, formless source from which all things arise and to which all return. Often translated as 'The Way,' the Tao is simultaneously the path of natural order, the cosmic process of change, and the ultimate reality beyond description. Paradoxically both empty and full, it operates through wu wei (non-action) and manifests in the harmonious flow of nature. The Tao cannot be fully grasped intellectually but can be experienced through alignment with its natural patterns. Understanding and following the Tao leads to harmony, wisdom, and spiritual realization.

properties.name: Nature
properties.value: Ineffable, nameless, formless, eternal, source of all

properties.name: Characteristics
properties.value: Empty yet inexhaustible, soft yet overcomes hard, natural and spontaneous

properties.name: Manifestation
properties.value: Through natural cycles, water's flow, spontaneous simplicity

properties.name: Paradox
properties.value: The Tao that can be spoken is not the eternal Tao

mythologyContexts.usage: Central principle of Daoism guiding spiritual practice, ethics, governance, and understanding of nature. The Tao is the source of yin-yang, qi, and the ten thousand things. Alignment with Tao leads to harmony, longevity, and spiritual realization

rituals.name: Wu Wei Practice
rituals.description: Cultivating effortless action in harmony with natural flow

rituals.name: Daoist Meditation
rituals.description: Quieting the mind to experience the Tao directly

rituals.name: Simplicity (Pu)
rituals.description: Returning to the uncarved block - original simplicity and naturalness

rituals.name: Contemplation of Nature
rituals.description: Observing water, wind, and natural cycles to understand the Tao's patterns

textReferences.context: The Tao that can be told is not the eternal Tao; the name that can be named is not the eternal Name
There was something undefined and complete, before heaven and earth... I call it Tao
Stories and parables illustrating the Tao's ineffable nature
Daoist canon's exploration of the Tao in philosophy, alchemy, and practice

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Tao is often symbolized by water - soft yet powerful, flowing yet persistent, seeking the lowest place yet essential to life. It represents the paradoxical wisdom that emptiness is fullness, weakness is strength, and non-action accomplishes all. The Tao symbolizes ultimate reality beyond all conceptual frameworks - the mystery at the heart of existence.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The Tao is the foundation of Daoism, one of China's three great philosophical-religious traditions. It has profoundly influenced Chinese art, poetry, governance, medicine, and martial arts. The concept has spread globally, inspiring Western philosophy, ecology, and spirituality. The Dao De Jing remains one of the world's most translated texts.
